title: Enterprise assets workflow
content:
This section describes the metaphases and subordinate phases in the life cycle of enterprise asset. The workflow of enterprise assets varies based on the their process types: Full Ownership, Consumable, and Stationary.

The workflow relies on business rules. Rules repeat from one phase to another when the end user can make a change to a field affected by a business rule during that phase. For more information about the out-of-the-box business rules defined for the enterprise asset workflow, see Enterprise asset process - Business rules.

Full Ownership

Metaphase: Unavailable

The asset enters into the system and is still awaiting delivery.

Phase Transition Description
New Automatic

New is a starting point.

Next phase: Awaiting Delivery
Awaiting Delivery Manual

The enterprise asset is in transit from a vendor or another provider.

Next phase: Receive or Cancelled

Example: the organization needs a refrigerator now. The appropriate manager requests a new refrigerator and the procurement team member creates a record for the new refrigerator when placing an order with an external vendor. Then the team member moves the record to the Awaiting Delivery phase because the asset isn't in use yet.

If the vendor can't complete the order, move the record manually to the final phase in the workflow: Cancelled.

Metaphase: Available

The asset has arrived but may or may not be available for use.

Phase Transition Description
Receive Manual

The asset has been delivered but isn't yet available to fulfill a request.

Next phase: In Stock
In Stock Manual

An asset is available to fulfill a request, and is stored in the specified stockroom.

Next phase: Maintenance, Prepare, or Retire
Maintenance Manual

The asset is defective and needs repair or requires periodic maintenance.

Next phase: Return to In Stock

Example: the status of the asset changes from Awaiting Delivery to Receive when the team member updates the record with the acquisition date. The asset owner captures more detailed information about the refrigerator and saves the record again. Now the status is In Stock.

Metaphase: In Use

The asset has arrived and is in pre-use preparation stages or is in use.

Phase Transition Description
Prepare Manual

The asset is being prepared for an end user or a production environment. Perhaps it requires configuration, testing, or customization before it's ready to use.

Next phase: In Use or return to In Stock
In Use Manual

The asset is functional in the enterprise environment.

Next phase: Retire or return to Prepare

Example: Tech Support installs and configures the refrigerator. The workflow phase is Prepare while it's being installed and configured. When the preparation is done, change the phase to In Use. If the refrigerator needs further preparation, you can return it to Tech Support (and the Prepare phase) for additional configuration

Metaphase: Retiring

The subordinate phase is Retire.

Phase Transition Description
Retire Manual

The asset is ready for retirement; it may still be used until a decision is made about its usage. It could be sent back to In Use or if it can't be used any longer, moved to End Of Life.

Next phase: Ended or return to In Use

Example: after ten years, the residual value of the refrigerator is almost zero and it's ready for replacement. The asset manager places a request for a new refrigerator and moves the current refrigerator to the Retire phase. It means the refrigerator is still in use but it's planned to retire it.

Metaphase: End Of Life (End)

The subordinate phases are Ended and Cancelled.

Phase Transition Description
Ended Manual

The asset is no longer in service.

In this phase, Service Management displays the Close code field. Choose one of the following codes:

  • Retired
  • Lost
  • Return to supplier
  • Stolen

Next phase: None
Cancelled None

The asset record is cancelled if the vendor or the organization cancels the order.

Next phase: None

Consumable

Metaphase: Unavailable

The asset enters into the system and is still awaiting delivery.

Phase Transition Description
New Automatic

New is a starting point.

Next phase: Awaiting Delivery
Awaiting Delivery Manual

The enterprise asset is in transit from a vendor or other provider.

Next phase: Receive or Cancelled

Example: the organization is finalizing the setup of a new administrative office. The appropriate manager requests a batch of 100 batteries. A procurement team member creates a record for the batteries when placing an order with an external vendor. Then the team member moves the record to Awaiting Delivery phase because the asset isn't in use yet.

If the vendor can't complete the order, move the record manually to the final phase in the workflow: Cancelled.

Metaphase: Available

The asset has arrived but may or may not be available for use.

Phase Transition Description
Receive Manual

The asset has been delivered but isn't yet available to fulfill a request.

Next phase: In Stock or In Use
In Stock Manual

An asset is available to fulfill a request, and is stored in the specified stockroom.

Next phase: Disposal or In Use

Example: the status of the asset changes from Awaiting Delivery to Receive when the team member updates the record with the acquisition date. The asset owner captures more detailed information about the batteries and saves the record again. Now the status is In Stock.

Metaphase: In Use

The asset has arrived and is in use.

Phase Transition Description
In Use Manual

The asset is functional in the enterprise environment.

Next phase: Disposal, Ended or return to In Stock

Example: Batteries have arrived and are distributed to team members for use.

Metaphase: Retiring

The subordinate phase is Disposal.

Phase Transition Description
Disposal Manual

The asset isn't suitable for use. It could be sent back In Stock in a stockroom or if it can't be used any longer, moved to End Of Life.

Next phase: Ended or return to In Stock

Example: The organization is running out of the batteries. The asset manager places a request for new batteries, and moves the current batteries to the Disposal phase.

Metaphase: End Of Life (End)

The subordinate phases are Ended and Cancelled.

Phase Transition Description
Ended Manual

The asset is no longer in service.

In this phase, Service Management displays the Close code field. Choose one of the following codes:

  • Retired
  • Lost
  • Return to supplier
  • Stolen

Next phase: None
Cancelled None

The asset record is cancelled if the vendor or the organization cancels the order

Next phase: None

Stationary

Metaphase: Unavailable

The asset enters into the system.

Phase Transition Description
New Automatic

New is a starting point.

Next phase: Ready

Example: The organization will activate a new conference room.

Metaphase: Available

The asset may or may not be available for use.

Phase Transition Description
Ready Manual

The asset isn't yet available to fulfill a request.

Next phase: In Use
Maintenance Manual

The asset is defective and needs repair or requires periodic maintenance.

Next phase: In Use

Example: The conference room is ready for use or in maintenance.

Metaphase: In Use

The asset is in use.

Phase Transition Description
In Use Manual

The asset is functional in the enterprise environment.

Next phase: Disposal or return to Maintenance

Example: The conference room is accessible to team members. If the conference room needs further repairs or decorations, you can return it to Maintenance.

Metaphase: Retiring

The subordinate phase is Disposal.

Phase Transition Description
Disposal Manual

The asset isn't suitable for use. It may still be used until a decision is made about its usage. It could be sent back In Use or if it can't be used any longer, moved to End Of Life.

Next phase: Ended or return to In Use

Example: The conference room requires an upgrade. It means the conference room is still in use but it's planned to retire it.

Metaphase: End Of Life (End)

The subordinate phases are Ended.

Phase Transition Description
Ended Manual

The asset is no longer in service.

In this phase, Service Management displays the Close code field. Choose one of the following codes:

  • Retired
  • Lost
  • Return to supplier
  • Stolen
